questions.text: Match the following? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. i. = c, ii. = a, iii. = d, iv. = b

 

i) Heroine = c) Brown sugar

 

ii) Joint = a) Ganja

 

iii) LSD = d) Acid

 

iv) Eve = b) Amphetamine

 

Explanation:

 

  • i. Heroin = c. Brown sugar
    • Heroin is a semi-synthetic opioid also known by street names such as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk.
  • ii. Joint = a. Ganja
    • A joint is a term used for a rolled marijuana cigarette. Ganja is also known as pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • iii. LSD = d. Acid
    • LSD is known by various street names including acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple owle.
  • iv. Eve = b. Amphetamine
    • Methamphetamine and related substances are often referred to as Eve, meth, etc.

 

Educational Objective

 

Street names of narcotic substances

 

  • Ganja is called Pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • Heroin is a semisynthetic opioid also known as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk
  •   Cocaine is called by names like snuff, Rock, Crack, Coke, Snow, Cadillac, White lady
  • Methamphetamine is also called eve, meth etc.
  • LSD is called by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple Owle.
  • Abrus Precatorius is called by names like Indian liquor ice, prayer head, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, gunja.
  • Capsaicin is called by names like 'Hunan hand' as it causes burning of fingers.

choices.text: Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus

questions.text: As an intern in emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum (i.e., N-E-X)

 

Approximate length of nasogastric tube is 120 -125cm     

 

How to confirm correct position of NG tube:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • x-ray chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

 

 

XIPHISTERNUM

 

Place the tip of the nasogastric tube at the tip of the nose, then measure from the nose to the ear lobe & down to the tip of the Xiphisternum

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus: This measurement is too long as it typically extends beyond the stomach, potentially reaching into the intestines.

 

Option C. Mouth to ear to umbilicus: This measurement is also incorrect and typically used for other medical estimations, not for NG tube placement.

 

Option D. Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus: Similar to option B, this measurement is excessively long for proper NG tube placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting a nasogastric tube, the correct measurement to estimate the necessary tube length is from the tip of the nose to the earlobe to the xiphisternum, ensuring the tube reaches the stomach properly for effective therapeutic or diagnostic use.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

 

Given image shows a Gall bladder specimen revealing numerous polyps.

 

Gall Bladder Polyp

 

Majority are either adenomyomatosis or cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential.

True adenomatous polyp occurs in 0.3–0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with increasing size of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholesterosis and Option D. Strawberry Gall bladder: The interior of the gallbladder looks something like a strawberry. The yellow specks (submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters) correspond to the seeds of a strawberry.

 

 

Option C. Gall bladder Carcinoma: Gall bladder Carcinoma specimen resemble chronic cholecystitis on gross examination, often with a thickened wall and possibly a mass. However, the image provided does not show the characteristics typically associated with carcinoma, such as a mass or irregular thickening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 79, 1709

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

choices.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the kidney and soft tissue. What is the reason for this super scan appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

 

Explanation:

 

The super scan appearance is due to increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis.

 

On a bone scan, a generalized increase in skeletal uptake relative to soft tissue and absent or faint renal activity. This is referred to as a super scan.

 

 

  • All the bones show diffusely increased uptake whereas kidneys are not visualized.
  • Seen with-
    1. Metabolic bone diseases
    2. Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased uptake by carcinoma prostate: While the primary prostate carcinoma may cause metastases, the increased uptake seen in a super scan specifically refers to bone metastases, not the primary tumor itself.

 

Option C. Increased uptake by the bone: This option is too general and does not specify the underlying cause, which in the context of a super scan is typically metastatic disease.

 

Option D. Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney: This choice misrepresents the scenario, as the decreased visualization of kidneys is a result of the intense skeletal uptake overshadowing other areas, not due to decreased uptake by these organs themselves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bone scan super scan appearance in a patient with known malignancy such as prostate cancer usually indicates extensive bone metastasis, necessitating aggressive management and treatment planning to address widespread disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Only Myasthenia gravis, among the conditions mentioned above, would show dramatic improvement after administration of an injection (Anti-ChE medication).

 

In myasthenia gravis, there is unilateral myogenic ptosis where, after a short rest, the symptoms recover rapidly.

 

A quick test in the office can be to ask the patient to look up and hold that position, and then observe if there is fatiguability of the levator muscle such that the upper eyelids start to drift downwards while the patient is looking up. The definitive diagnosis is made through various clinical, pharmacological and serologic tests.

 

Diagnostic Tests

 

1. Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test:

 

Edrophonium chloride inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby prolonging the presence of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This results in enhanced muscle strength. This test is only useful in patients with objective, measurable findings on physical exam, like ptosis or a tropia. In ptosis, a positive test is the elevation of eyelids in 2-5 minutes post administration of Tensilon. A negative response is no improvement within 3 minutes.

 

2. Ice Test:

 

This is also a simple diagnostic test that can be done in the clinic. It is highly sensitive and specific for MG. The ice test is useful for ptosis. An ice pack is applied to the affected upper eyelid for 2-5 minutes. A positive test is the improvement of ptosis by > 2mm or more. This transient improvement in ptosis is due to the cold decreasing the acetylcholinesterase break-down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th nerve palsy: This condition primarily causes abduction deficit (inability to move the eye laterally), which would not explain the ptosis nor improve with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option C. 3rd nerve palsy: Though it can cause ptosis and eye movement abnormalities, symptoms are due to mechanical dysfunctions or nerve damage and do not improve quickly with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option D. Horner syndrome: Characterized by ptosis, miosis (pupil constriction), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating), but does not involve hypotropia or improve dramatically with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane.
  • The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.
  • Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features.
  • A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Note:

 

The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fiber Electromyography

 

The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: A 38-year-old civil engineer is working on a construction project in an area recently affected by a devastating earthquake. To prevent future devastation, the local government has amended the building codes. These changes are aimed at ensuring structures in the area can better withstand seismic activity. The engineer reviews the changes to determine the best approach for the new construction project. This modification to the building codes is primarily an example of which phase of disaster management? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Disaster mitigation

 

  • The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Mitigation involves measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing an emergency or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. In most cases mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system.

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

 

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.  

 

   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster mitigation involves proactive measures such as improved building codes to reduce the impact of future disasters, aiming to lessen vulnerability and enhance resilience against potential hazards.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in rheumatoid arthritis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Febuxostat

 

Febuxostat is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor primarily used as a hypouricemic agent for managing gout by reducing uric acid production. Its primary function is to alleviate the symptoms and prevent the recurrence of gout, not to treat inflammatory or autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Leflunomide: Incorrect choice for the given answer as Leflunomide is indeed used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that works by suppressing the immune system to reduce inflammation.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Incorrect because Methotrexate is a cornerstone treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. It is another DMARD that helps reduce joint damage and decrease the pain and swelling associated with RA.

 

Option D. Etanercept: Incorrect as it is also used in rheumatoid arthritis treatment. Etanercept is a TNF (tumor necrosis factor) inhibitor, which is a type of biologic therapy that helps to decrease inflammation and slow disease progression in RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febuxostat is specifically used to manage gout by lowering uric acid levels and does not have a role in the treatment regimen for rheumatoid arthritis, which typically involves DMARDs and biologic agents aimed at controlling systemic inflammation and preventing joint damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap 358

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favipiravir

 

Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that has been studied for use in COVID-19, but its effectiveness, particularly in severe cases, is less clear compared to other treatments. Favipiravir is known to work against RNA viruses, but its role in the treatment of severe COVID-19 has not been established as a standard of care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Patients with severe COVID-19 are at increased risk of thromboembolic events. LMWH is used to prevent blood clots and is an important part of the management of hospitalized COVID-19 patients, especially those with severe disease.

 

Option B. Oxygen: Oxygen therapy is crucial for patients with severe COVID-19, especially those experiencing respiratory distress and hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels). It is a key supportive treatment.

 

Option D. Steroids: Corticosteroids like dexamethasone have been shown to reduce mortality in patients with severe and critical COVID-19, particularly those requiring respiratory support. They are used to reduce inflammation in the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Favipiravir is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19 compared to low molecular weight heparin, oxygen, and steroids, which have well-established roles in managing severe cases of the disease.

questions.text: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroxine

 

Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.

 

The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process. Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Epinephrine: Incorrect. Epinephrine is a catecholamine that acts on cell surface receptors (adrenergic receptors) and does not cross the plasma membrane to exert its effects.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Incorrect. Glucagon is a peptide hormone that binds to receptors on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Option D. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin is a peptide hormone that binds to its receptor on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Educational objective

 

Thyroxine (T4) crosses the plasma membrane and binds to intracellular receptors to exert its effects, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis.

choices.text: Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

questions.text: A pregnant female with known cardiac disease presents in the first trimester with history of warfarin embryopathy. What should be advised now? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

 

Warfarin readily crosses the placenta and is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly when exposure occurs between the 6th and 9th weeks of pregnancy. Warfarin embryopathy is characterized by stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia.

 

Management guidelines for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves requiring anticoagulation:

 

  • First trimester: Women on warfarin should be switched to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed to avoid teratogenic effects.
  • Second and third trimesters (13 to 36 weeks): Warfarin can be resumed as it is the most effective anticoagulant in preventing thromboembolic events.
  • Near delivery: Warfarin should be switched back to heparin around delivery to avoid complications. Heparin should be stopped prior to delivery.

 

Mechanical heart valves: Require lifelong anticoagulation, whereas bioprosthetic valves do not require lifelong anticoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin throughout the pregnancy: Continuing warfarin throughout the pregnancy is not advisable due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy and potential fetal hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Give accoumarin: Accoumarin is not a standard recommendation for anticoagulation in pregnant women with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option D. Use LMW heparin: While low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is safer in pregnancy compared to warfarin, the specific recommendation is to switch to heparin in the first trimester and possibly back to warfarin in the second and third trimesters, depending on individual risk assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with mechanical heart valves on warfarin, switch to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed in the first trimester to avoid teratogenic effects, and manage anticoagulation carefully throughout the pregnancy to minimize risks to both mother and fetus.

 

 

Algorithm for management of women with prosthetic heart valves requiring anti-coagulation in pregnancy

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 2406

choices.text: Loss of taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue
Loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of motor sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue

questions.text: Fracture of the jugular canal can present as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue

 

Fracture of the jugular canal affects the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and presents as a loss of taste sensation in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

 

  • The lingual nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, gives general sensation to the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve gives taste sensation to the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.
  • Both taste and general sensation of the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue are provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.
  • The muscles of the tongue, with the exception of the palatoglossus, are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. The palatoglossus is supplied by the pharyngeal plexus.

 

The other nerves passing through the jugular foramen are the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) and the accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI), which may also be involved in cases of jugular canal fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue: This sensation is mediated by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve. A fracture of the jugular canal would not affect this part of the tongue.

 

Option C. Loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue: This is mediated by the lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), which is not involved in jugular canal fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of motor sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue: Motor innervation of the tongue is supplied by the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), which is not affected by jugular canal fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fracture of the jugular canal can lead to a loss of taste sensation in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue due to damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

choices.text: Blighted ovum
﻿﻿﻿Missed abortion
﻿﻿﻿Ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatidiform mole

 

Explanation:


The typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’ on ultrasound is indicative of a hydatidiform mole. This appearance is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy, where there is a proliferation of abnormal tissue instead of a viable embryo.

 

  • Complete Mole:
    • Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity.
    • Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY.
      • Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
    • Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • Partial Mole:
    • Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum.
    • Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blighted ovum: Also known as an anembryonic pregnancy, this occurs when a gestational sac forms but no embryo is visible. It does not present with the Snowstorm appearance and usually lacks the pronounced proliferation of tissue seen in a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option B. Missed abortion: This involves the retention of an embryo or fetus with no detectable heartbeat or growth. The ultrasound findings typically show a non-viable fetus without the characteristic snowstorm pattern of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: This occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tubes. It would not present with the Snowstorm appearance but rather show a gestational sac or products of conception in an abnormal location.

 

Educational Objective:


The 'Snowstorm appearance' on transvaginal ultrasound is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Ref: Page no 225, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text:
Which of these is the definition of effective CPR?

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute.
  2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min.
  3. Allow complete chest recoil.
  4. 5-6 cm depression.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3 and 4

 

Components of High-Quality CPR:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Effective CPR includes the following components:

 

  • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest.
  • Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation.
  • 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.

 

Other Option:

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Effective CPR is characterized by chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, allowing complete chest recoil, and compressing the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2529-2534

questions.text: After visiting a village temple with his grandmother, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Considering his condition, what treatment approach would you choose for his management? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prazosin

 

This is a case of scorpion bite. The key characteristic feature of scorpion bite is autonomic storm, and sometimes cholinergic storm. This subject is having the features of both storms as described below.

 

Scorpion Toxins affect various ion channels. By acting on sodium (excitation) and potassium (blocking) channels, the toxin prolongs depolarization at postsynaptic postganglionic nerve terminals of ANS. This cause a massive release of sympathetic and parasympathetic mediators, resulting in mixed neuroexcitatory syndrome.

 

Clinical Manifestations of Scorpion bite: Main manifestation of scorpion bite is adrenergic (autonomic storm). Sometimes Cholinergic (muscarinic) storm occurs.

 

  • Adrenergic Storm: Overstimulation of sympathetic system result in “adrenergic storm” which consists of cardiac (tachycardia, peripheral vasoconstriction, hypertension, diaphoresis), metabolic (hyperthermia, hyperglycaemia), urogenital (urinary retention), respiratory (bronchial dilation, tachypnea), and neuromuscular (mydriasis, tremor, agitation, convulsions).

 

  • Cholinergic syndrome: Overstimulation of parasympathetic system result in a hypersecretion syndrome (salivation, sweating, vomiting, urinary incontinence, bronchial hypersecretion, and diarrhea), abdominal pain, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia with hypotension and, in the male, priapism.

 

Management:

 

  • Prazosin–a post-synaptic alpha1, adreno-receptor antagonist–is the first line of management. It suppresses sympathetic outflow and activates K channels.
  • Scorpion Antivenom: Scorpion venom act very fast. Anti-venom has to be given within 30 minutes of sting to be effective. So anti-venom is useful only in limited cases which present very early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Anti-snake venom: Not useful in scorpion bite

 

Option B) Methylprednisolone:  Steroids are not useful in scorpion bite, and moreover steroids might enhance the necrotizing effects of catecholamines on myocardium.

 

Option D) Adrenaline: It will further worsen autonomic storm

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the first-line treatment for scorpion envenomation due to its ability to suppress sympathetic outflow and mitigate the effects of the autonomic storm.

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Calcium deposition occurs primarily in the zone of calcified cartilage, which is represented by option D in the image. This zone is located near the metaphysis of a growing bone, where cartilage is being replaced by bone tissue. The calcification process involves the accumulation of calcium salts in the cartilage matrix, leading to its hardening and subsequent replacement by bone. This is a crucial step in the endochondral ossification process, which allows for the longitudinal growth of bones.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This layer represents the reserve zone, where chondrocytes are relatively inactive and not yet undergoing proliferation or hypertrophy. Calcium deposition does not occur in this zone.

 

Option B: This layer is the proliferative zone, where chondrocytes are rapidly dividing. While important for bone growth, this zone does not involve calcium deposition.

 

Option C: This is the hypertrophic zone, where chondrocytes increase in size and prepare for calcification. Although it is a precursor to the calcification process, actual calcium deposition occurs in the next zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

questions.text: All of the options listed can be utilized for assessing data normalcy except? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mantel-Haenszel test

 

  • The Mantel Haenszel test is used for sample sets that are able to be placed in two by two tables, but unlike the Fisher Exact test and the chi-squared test, there is no “n” requirement.
  • Normality of a data refers to a specific statistical distribution called a normal distribution, or sometimes the Gaussian distribution or bell-shaped curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plot histogram: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A histogram can visually show whether data follow a normal distribution.

 

Option C. Box whisker: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A box-and-whisker plot (box plot) can reveal the symmetry and spread of data, indicating normality.

 

Option D. Shapiro Wilk test: Correct for assessing data normalcy. The Shapiro-Wilk test is a statistical test specifically designed to test the normality of data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mantel-Haenszel test is not used for assessing the normality of data. Normality can be assessed using tools like plot histograms, box-and-whisker plots, Shapiro-Wilk test, Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, etc.

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

 

On the fourth day, this child's bilirubin level is only 8 mg/dl, indicating physiologic jaundice. Because the child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding on a regular and exclusive basis.

 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is caused by increased bilirubin production from foetal red blood cell breakdown combined with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation by the immature neonatal liver.

 

It usually appears on the second or third day after birth, peaks on the fourth day at 5-6 mg/dL, and then drops to 2 mg/dL between the fifth and seventh days.

 

Note: Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

 

  1. Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth.
  2. Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant.
  3. Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level.
  4. Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) levels above the expected normal range -Jaundice is seen in the mid-abdomen (= 15 mg/dL) and soles (- 20 mg/dL).
  5. Total Serum Bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy.
  6. Total Serum Bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exchange transfusion: exchange transfusion is not the correct option.

 

Indications of exchange transfusion are:

 

  1. History of Direct coombs test positive
  2. Cord hemoglobin < 5gm/cl and cord bilirubin >10 mg /dl
  3. History of sibling death / erythroblastosis fetalis

 

Option B. Stop breastfeeding and start phototherapy: We don’t stop breast feeding unless the baby is a case of galactosemia or lactose intolerance because in these conditions breast feeding is contraindicated.

 

Option C. IV fluids and phototherapy: IV fluids is not the right option as the baby is feeding well. We don’t give IV fluids to a baby who is feeding well.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Drug of choice to treat this condition is? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:


The patient presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV). In bacterial vaginosis, the correct treatment is Metronidazole.

 

  • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include:
    1. Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge: The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor.
    2. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5: This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina.
    3. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test): The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide.
    4. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy: Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.

 

Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, and it is typically administered as oral tablets (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: While Clindamycin can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it is generally not the first choice. Metronidazole is preferred due to its effectiveness and established use.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is used for a variety of bacterial infections but is not effective for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:


The drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The presentation of a child with a type B tympanometry curve indicates the likelihood of serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy as the underlying cause.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: While this can relieve middle ear effusion, it does not address the underlying adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Similar to grommet insertion alone, this option does not address the root cause of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: This procedure involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid but does not address the cause or provide a lasting solution like adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the most appropriate management for a child presenting with serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy, addressing both the immediate symptoms and underlying cause.

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

 

  • The correct description of the given fractures are:

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.

 

 

2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.

 

 

3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.

 

 

4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.

questions.text: Hawkins's classification is used for which fractures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talus


Hawkins's classification is specifically used for fractures of the neck of the talus. These fractures typically result from high-energy injuries, such as forced dorsiflexion with an axial load, often seen in motor vehicle accidents or falls. Hawkins's classification is valuable in assessing the severity of the fracture and the risk of avascular necrosis, which is a critical concern with talar neck injuries. The classification includes the following types:

 

  • Type I: Undisplaced fracture.
  • Type II: Fracture with subtalar dislocation.
  • Type III: Fracture with subtalar and tibiotalar dislocation.
  • Type IV: Fracture with subtalar, tibiotalar, and talonavicular dislocation.

 

Undisplaced fractures (Type I) can be managed conservatively with immobilization, while displaced fractures (Types II-IV) typically require surgical intervention, such as open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Navicular: Hawkins's classification is not used for navicular fractures. Navicular fractures are relatively rare and have their own classification systems, mainly focusing on avulsion fractures and stress fractures.

 

Option C. Tibia: Tibial fractures, including both diaphyseal and distal tibial fractures, are classified using systems like the AO/OTA classification rather than Hawkins's classification.

 

Option D. Calcaneum: The classification of calcaneal fractures is more commonly done using the Sanders classification, which is based on CT imaging. Hawkins's classification is not applicable to calcaneal fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hawkins's classification is specifically used for fractures of the neck of the talus, assessing the severity and risk of complications like avascular necrosis. Understanding this classification aids in determining the appropriate management and prognosis of talar neck fractures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a palpable lump in her breast. Which of the following investigations cannot be used to rule out malignancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PET scan

 

In the evaluation of a breast lump or any suspicious symptoms, the triple assessment method is used. It involves clinical assessment, radiological examination, and cytological or histological examination. The combination of these three modalities has a high positive predictive value of 99.99% to exclude breast cancer.

 

Positron emission tomography (PET) scans are not typically used as part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. PET scans use a radioactive tracer to produce detailed images of the body and are more commonly used to evaluate cancers that have spread to other parts of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiological investigations: Radiological investigations such as mammography or ultrasound are commonly used as part of the triple assessment method to evaluate a breast lump. These tests help to identify any suspicious areas in the breast tissue that may require further evaluation with a biopsy.

 

Option C. Clinical examination: Clinical examination, including physical examination and assessment of medical history, is an important part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. This can help to identify any specific risk factors for breast cancer and assess the characteristics of the lump, such as size, shape, and texture.

 

Option D. Histology and cytology: Histology and cytology are essential parts of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or core biopsy of the lump helps to establish a definitive diagnosis and determine whether the lump is benign or malignant. The sample is then examined under a microscope to determine the characteristics of the cells and provide further information about the tumor, such as the stage and grade.

choices.text: To break AT bonds high Tm is required
To break GC bonds low Tm is required
To break AT bonds low Tm is required
AT bonds and GC bonds need the same TM

questions.text: Which of the following is true? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To break AT bonds low Tm is required

 

To break AT bonds low Tm is required: This statement is correct. AT bonds are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are relatively weak compared to GC bonds. Therefore, lower temperatures (low Tm) are required to break AT bonds, causing the DNA to denature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To break AT bonds high Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. The melting temperature (Tm) of DNA is the temperature at which the double-stranded DNA molecule begins to denature or separate into single strands. AT bonds (adenine-thymine) are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are weaker than the three hydrogen bonds holding GC bonds (guanine-cytosine) together. Therefore, lower temperatures (relatively low Tm) are required to break AT bonds.

 

Option B. To break GC bonds low Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. GC bonds have a higher Tm compared to AT bonds because they are held together by three hydrogen bonds, making them more stable. So, higher temperatures (relatively high Tm) are required to break GC bonds.

 

Option D. AT bonds and GC bonds need the same Tm: This statement is incorrect. As explained above, AT bonds and GC bonds have different Tm values due to the difference in the number of hydrogen bonds holding them together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, there are two hydrogen bonds between A and T and three hydrogen bonds between G and C. So, AT bonds will require a lower Tm (melting temperature) compared to GC bonds as less energy is required for breaking 2 bonds compared to three bonds.

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ptosis of right eye

 

The patient has ptosis of the right eye. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea. Ptosis is generally unilateral, in over 70% of individuals. The drooping in this case is significant enough to cover a portion of the pupil, thereby obstructing part of the visual field, which is characteristic of ptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entropion of right eye: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid margin, not observed in the provided image.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos of right eye: Refers to the inability to close the eyelids completely, not evident here.

 

Option D. Exophthalmos of left eye: Characterized by the protrusion of the eyeball, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis, particularly of the type seen in this patient, is typically caused by a dysfunction or disconnection of the levator muscle or its aponeurosis, either congenital or acquired.

 

Types:

 

 

Note: Pseudoptosis is apparent but not true drooping of the eyelid. Causes include lack of support of the lids by the globe (orbital volume deficit like an artificial eye, microphthalmos, or enophthalmos), contralateral lid retraction, ipsilateral hypotropia, brow ptosis, or dermatochalasis.

questions.text: Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. So, on SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is likely to occur? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process used for plasma can safely inactivate all lipid-enveloped virus. HAV is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it's not affected by solvent/detergent (SD) plasma.

 

Hepatitis B, C, and HIV are enveloped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV): HIV is an enveloped virus. The SD process effectively inactivates HIV by disrupting its lipid envelope, making it non-infectious.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBV is also an enveloped virus. The SD process disrupts the lipid envelope of HBV, rendering it non-infectious.

 

Option D. Hepatitis C Virus (HCV): HCV is another enveloped virus. The SD process targets and inactivates HCV by disrupting its lipid envelope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process inactivates lipid-enveloped viruses such as HIV, HBV, and HCV. However, it does not inactivate non-enveloped viruses like Hepatitis A Virus (HAV), making HAV infections a potential risk during SD plasma transfusion.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

 

  1. Iliococcygeus
  2. Pubococcygeus
  3. Obturator internus
  4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B

 

Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani.

 

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit that consists of three muscle components:

 

  1. Pubococcygeus:
    • Pubovaginalis: Elevates the urethra and contributes to urinary continence.
    • Puboperinealis: Draws the perineal body toward the pubic symphysis.
    • Puboanalis: Elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed.
  2. Puborectalis
  3. Iliococcygeus

 

The levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces. Weakening of the levator ani and pelvic fascia, such as through stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum, or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Obturator internus: The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

 

Option D. Deep transverse perinei: The deep transverse perineal muscle is located in the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body. It is not part of the pelvic diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm, also known as the levator ani, consists of the iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. These muscles provide essential support to the pelvic organs and play a critical role in maintaining continence and pelvic stability.

questions.text: The image given below is a type of _______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contusion

 

The type of injury shown in the image is a contusion.

 

A contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.

 

  • A pure bruise lies beneath an intact epidermis.
  • Bruises are caused by damage to veins, venules, and small arteries.
  • The usual bruise from a blunt impact is situated in the subcutaneous tissues, often in the fat layer. (Fat individuals tend to bruise more easily than thin individuals due to the greater volume of soft subcutaneous tissue.)
  • Delayed bruising is a common phenomenon, where a bruise may become more prominent after hours or days due to continued bleeding from ruptured vessels, with blood percolating from deeper tissues toward the epidermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abrasion: Abrasion, also known as gravel rash, is the destruction of the superficial layers of the epidermis, usually due to friction against a rough surface. Abrasions can be classified into scratches, grazes, pressure abrasions, or impact abrasions.

 

Option C. Laceration: Laceration refers to a tear or split of the skin, mucous membranes, or muscles caused by blunt force trauma. The shape and depth of a laceration can help determine the cause of the injury.

 

Option D. Stab wound: A stab wound is caused by a sharp object (e.g., knife or scissors), producing a wound that is deeper than it is wide with clean, inverted edges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contusions are caused by blunt force trauma, leading to subcutaneous bleeding (bruising) without breaking the skin. The delayed appearance of bruises is common, and their progression provides clues to the timing and severity of the injury.

questions.text: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as developmental delay? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding by spoon


Feeding with a spoon is a social milestone that typically develops around 18 months of age. If a child is unable to feed themselves with a spoon by 24 months, it can be considered a developmental delay. By the age of 3 years, most children should have well-established self-feeding skills, including the ability to hold and use a spoon effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one leg: This milestone typically develops around 4 years of age. It would not be considered a delay if a 3-year-old is unable to hop on one leg.

 

Option B. Drawing a square: Drawing a square is a fine motor skill that generally develops around 4 and a half years of age, so its absence at 3 years old is not considered a delay.

 

Option D. Passing a ball to someone: This social and motor skill usually develops around 4 years of age. Therefore, a 3-year-old not being able to pass a ball would not be considered delayed.

 

Educational Objective:


The absence of feeding with a spoon by 24 months can indicate a developmental delay in social and motor skills in a child.

questions.text: Which nerve is biopsied for the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic leprosy? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial branch of radial nerve

 

Superficial branch of radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy.

 

Pure neuritic leprosy is characterized by asymmetrical involvement of peripheral nerve trunks without visible skin lesions.

 

  • To confirm the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy, nerve biopsy is considered the gold standard. It is essential to biopsy only sensory nerves and avoid motor or major nerve trunks, as well as mixed nerves.
  • For nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy, the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is typically utilized.

 

 

  • The biopsy sample should be taken from a purely sensory thickened peripheral nerve, such as the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist, ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand, or sural nerve near the ankle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve and Option C. Ulnar nerve are less frequently chosen for biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy due to their mixed sensory and motor functions, which could lead to functional deficits if damaged.

 

Option D. Lateral popliteal nerve also known as the common peroneal nerve, is generally avoided in routine nerve biopsies for leprosy due to its deeper location and the significant motor components it controls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic Leprosy, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the preferred site for biopsy due to its accessibility, lower risk of complications, and high diagnostic yield.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.11 28.14

Sensory reanimation of the hand by transfer of the superficial branch of the radial nerve to the median and ulnar nerve - Scientific Figure on ResearchGate. Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Transfer-of-the-superficial-branch-of-the-radial-nerve-SBRN-to-the-median-nerve-MN_fig5_309138539 [accessed 9 Nov, 2023]

questions.text: What will the corrected reticulocyte count if Hb is 5 g/dl and absolute reticulocyte count is 9%? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 

 

Calculation:

 

Average Hb value to be taken as 15 g/dl.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is essential in evaluating the bone marrow response in anemic patients. It is calculated by adjusting the absolute reticulocyte count according to the degree of anemia (using actual and normal hemoglobin values).

questions.text: Which procedure amongst the following has the highest probability of ureteric injury? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wertheim's hysterectomy

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the radical nature of the procedure. Wertheim's hysterectomy, also known as radical hysterectomy, involves extensive dissection and removal of not only the uterus but also the surrounding tissues, including the parametria and the upper part of the vagina. This extensive dissection increases the risk of ureteric injury.

 

However, it's important to note that while Wertheim's hysterectomy carries a higher individual risk for ureteric injury due to its radical nature, the most common cause of ureteric injury overall is abdominal hysterectomy, simply because it is the most commonly performed type of hysterectomy.

 

The overall incidence of ureteric injury in all pelvic operations is about 0.5-1%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abdominal hysterectomy: Although it is the most common cause of ureteric injury due to its high frequency, the individual risk per procedure is lower than that of Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Vaginal hysterectomy: This procedure has a lower risk of ureteric injury compared to abdominal and Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Anterior colporrhaphy: This procedure, which is used to repair the anterior vaginal wall, has a much lower risk of ureteric injury compared to hysterectomy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the extensive dissection involved in the procedure.

 

The risk of ureteric injury is highest with a radical hysterectomy followed laparoscopic or robotic hysterectomy followed by abdominal hysterectomy and least risk is with vaginal hysterectomy

 

Ref: TeLinde’s Operative gynecology 12th edition

questions.text:
Correct sequence after p wave: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A- 'a' wave

B- 1st heart sound

C-Rapid filling of ventricles

D- 't' wave
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABDC

 

Following the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization leading to atrial contraction:

 

A- 'a' wave occurs as a result of atrial contraction, pushing blood into the ventricles.

 

B- 1st heart sound is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of ventricular systole.

 

D- 't' wave represents the repolarization of the ventricles, indicating the beginning of ventricular relaxation.

 

C- Rapid filling of ventricles follows as the ventricles relax and the atrioventricular valves open, allowing blood to flow from the higher pressure atria to the relaxed ventricles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical events precede mechanical events in cardiac homeostasis

 

P wave→ Atrial contraction (a wave).

 

QRS→ ventricular contraction (C wave)

 

T wave→ Ventricular relaxation (Early rapid filling (Y descent)

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Clinical/ chap 239

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bipolar cautery

 

The given instrument is a Bipolar cautery

 

  • Bipolar cautery, like unipolar cautery, is a form of electrosurgery used for tissue coagulation and hemostasis.
  • Unlike unipolar cautery, bipolar cautery uses two electrodes that are very close together on the surgical instrument. The electrical current flows only between these two closely spaced electrodes, which limits the current's path to a small area of tissue.
  • Bipolar cautery is often preferred in delicate surgical procedures where precise tissue coagulation is required, as it has a more localized effect compared to unipolar cautery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unipolar cautery: 

 

  • Unipolar cautery is a type of electrosurgery that uses a single electrode for cutting or coagulating tissue. It is commonly used for various surgical procedures to cut or coagulate tissues, control bleeding, and achieve hemostasis.

 

 

Option C. The harmonic scalpel:

 

  • The harmonic scalpel is known for its precision and minimal thermal spread, making it suitable for various surgical procedures, including laparoscopic and open surgeries.
  • It allows surgeons to dissect tissues and achieve hemostasis with minimal damage to surrounding structures, based on generation of heat from ultrasonic waves.

 

 

Option D. LigaSure vessel sealing system:

 

  • LigaSure is known for its ability to create secure and consistent vessel seals, reducing the risk of bleeding during surgery.
  • It is a type of advanced bipolar vessel sealing device.
  • It is commonly used in a wide range of surgical specialties, including general surgery, gynecology, and urology, among others.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar cautery is ideal for controlled, precise tissue coagulation in delicate surgeries due to its localized current flow, making it more specific than unipolar cautery.

questions.text: Dialysis will prevent all except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral Neuropathy

 

Dialysis is effective in removing many waste products and toxins from the blood, which can alleviate a range of symptoms associated with uremia. However, it is less effective in preventing or reversing complications that arise from the accumulation of middle molecular weight substances, such as those implicated in peripheral neuropathy.

 

 

Peripheral neuropathy in dialysis patients is largely attributed to the build-up of middle molecular weight molecules like beta 2 microglobulin, which are not efficiently removed by standard dialysis membranes. Native kidneys or high-flux dialyzers are more effective at removing these molecules, but even these can have limited efficacy. Peripheral neuropathy is thus a complication less responsive to conventional dialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seizures: These are often caused by severe uremia or electrolyte imbalances, both of which can be effectively managed through dialysis.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Dialysis helps correct metabolic acidosis by removing excess acids from the blood and restoring bicarbonate levels.

 

Option D. Uremic pericarditis: Uremic toxins that contribute to inflammatory conditions such as pericarditis are effectively removed through dialysis, thereby preventing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While dialysis effectively manages many complications of renal failure such as seizures, metabolic acidosis, and uremic pericarditis, it is less effective for peripheral neuropathy due to its limited ability to remove middle molecular weight toxins that contribute to nerve damage. Ongoing management and treatment strategies need to consider these limitations.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Nephrology, Dialysis

questions.text: An esteemed research institute recently conducted a comprehensive study on individuals diagnosed with HIV to understand the progression and current health status of the participants. As a part of this study, the CD4 count, which plays a critical role in assessing the immune status of these individuals, was meticulously measured. Given the graphical representation provided that depicts the distribution of CD4 counts, can you infer the average CD4 count range that can be derived from this graph? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 300-400

 

If we convert the given graph data into a table, it will be as follows:


 

To determine the midpoint of each provided interval, it is necessary to calculate the midpoint for each interval individually. Following this, the resulting midpoints should be multiplied by the corresponding interval frequencies.

 

Mean = Sum of all observations / number of observations.

 

 

Mean = 34500/100 = 345.

 

Hence, 300 -400 is the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When interpreting a frequency distribution graph like this for CD4 counts in HIV-positive individuals, it's essential to compute the weighted average based on the midpoint of each interval and the frequency of observations within each interval.
  • This provides a more accurate assessment of the overall average CD4 count, crucial for understanding the immune status in a clinical setting.

choices.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes
Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts
Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys
Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys

questions.text: PTH increases Calcium in blood. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) primarily acts to increase the concentration of calcium in the blood. It achieves this through several mechanisms:

  1. Stimulation of osteoclasts to resorb bone, leading to the release of calcium from the bones.
  2. Increased absorption of calcium in the intestines.
  3. Stimulation of the kidneys to reabsorb more calcium, reducing its excretion in the urine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes: Osteocytes are embedded in the bone matrix and are not directly involved in the rapid release of calcium. Osteoclasts, on the other hand, are responsible for bone resorption.

 

Option B. Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts: Osteoclasts are indeed involved in the rapid release of calcium from bones. However, the complete action of PTH includes not only osteoclast activity but also increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys: While PTH does stimulate increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, the complete action also involves the rapid release of calcium from bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating calcium levels in the blood and the mechanisms by which it accomplishes this task.

 

  • Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range.
  • Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes:
    • Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream.
    • Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body.
    • Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.

questions.text: Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC include all except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 7 days admission in hospital

 

The duration of hospital stay alone does not define grievous hurt under IPC 320. The nature and severity of the injury are the determining factors, not the length of hospitalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC:

 

Option A. Permanent privation of hearing: This is considered grievous hurt as it results in the permanent loss of a sense, causing significant and lasting disability.

 

Option B. Fracture femur: Fracture of the femur is explicitly mentioned under IPC 320 as grievous hurt due to the severity and potential long-term consequences of the injury.

 

Option D. Emasculation: This involves depriving a man of his masculine vigour and is considered grievous hurt due to the significant physical and psychological impact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grievous hurt under IPC 320 involves injuries that cause permanent disability, severe bodily pain, or life-altering effects. Hospital stay duration alone does not qualify an injury as grievous hurt unless accompanied by a severe or specified injury under the law.

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.text: A female patient presents with active genital warts with a history of recurrence, but her husband doesn't have it. What advice will you give to prevent transmission? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

 

  • This is the correct answer. Avoiding sexual contact when active lesions are present is one of the most effective ways to prevent the transmission of HPV.
  • Genital warts are primarily caused by specific types of human papillomavirus (HPV-6 and HPV-11).
  • These warts, also known as venereal warts or condyloma acuminata, are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact.
  • However, they can also be transmitted through non-sexual means.
  • Genital warts are highly contagious when lesions are active, so abstaining from sexual activity during these times is crucial to prevent spread to partners.

 

 

Management of Genital warts:

 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are the primary drugs recommended as first-line treatments for genital warts. Imiquimod stimulates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, inducing apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • Imiquimod cream is approved for the treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts through topical immunomodulation
  • The most effective method to prevent the transmission of infection is to abstain from sexual intercourse when active lesions are present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient.

 

  • This is not the correct approach because continuous prophylaxis with antivirals is not typically recommended for genital warts, which are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • Antivirals are more commonly used for other viral infections like herpes simplex virus.
  • Moreover, prophylaxis doesn't prevent the transmission of HPV during periods without active lesions.

 

Option B. Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband.

 

  • This option is incorrect for similar reasons as option A. HPV, the virus causing genital warts, does not have a prophylactic antiviral treatment.
  • Furthermore, since the husband does not have active lesions or a history of genital warts, prophylactic treatment is not indicated.

 

Option C. Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present.

 

  • While this might seem like a reasonable approach, it is important to note that antivirals are not effective against HPV.
  • Treatment for active genital warts typically involves topical agents or procedures like cryotherapy, not systemic antiviral medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by HPV, it is advisable to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present, as there are no effective antiviral prophylaxis options for HPV, and HPV transmission risk is highest during periods with active lesions.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998

choices.text: Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour
Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 1 includes: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, spontaneous labour

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification specifically includes:

 

  • Nulliparous: A woman who has never given birth before.
  • Singleton: A pregnancy involving only one fetus.
  • Cephalic: The fetal presentation is head-down.
  • ≥37 weeks: The pregnancy is at or beyond 37 weeks of gestation.
  • Spontaneous labour: Labour onset is spontaneous, not induced or via cesarean section.

 

This classification is used to categorize pregnant women for analyzing obstetric outcomes, interventions, and cesarean section rates. The Modified Robson’s classification is a system developed by the World Health Organization to help in understanding and comparing cesarean section rates and labor outcomes across different settings.

 

 

Robson’s 10 groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour: This option describes Class 2 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Option C. Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour: This option describes Class 3 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Option D. Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour: This option describes Class 4 of the Modified Robson's classification, which includes multiparous women (without previous cesarean section) with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and have induced labor or a cesarean section before labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class 1 of the Modified Robson's classification includes nulliparous women with a singleton cephalic fetus who are ≥37 weeks and are in spontaneous labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/259512/9789241513197-eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: Which mutation is seen in sickle cell disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glu → Val (6)

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a specific point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val). This single amino acid substitution leads to the formation of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS), which polymerizes under deoxygenated conditions, causing red blood cells to become sickle-shaped.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val).

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: A study involved 30,000 women who were monitored for a period of 10 years to track the occurrence of breast cancer. Among them, 1200 women developed cancer and were subsequently given a questionnaire to evaluate potential risk factors. In parallel, 2000 women from the same study served as controls and were also subjected to the questionnaire. What is the name of this type of study? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Nested case control

 

  • Given scenario dictates that a population was monitored for development of breast cancer.
  • Out of which, 1200 women developed breast cancer and a small subgroup was taken as control.
  • This study structure points to Nested case control study.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Cohort study involves selecting Exposed and non-exposed groups then follow them for development of outcome.

 

Option B. Retrospective cohort: In Retrospective cohort, the outcomes have already occurred before the study begins.

 

Option D. Cross control cohort: Cross control cohort is not a study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A nested case-control study involves identifying cases and controls from an existing cohort that is being followed over time, making it a cost-effective way to study the associations between exposures and outcomes.

questions.text:
Match the following positions of the appendix: (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Subcaecal
  2. Retrocaecal
  3. Inside the pelvis
  4. Paracaecal
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

choices.text: Can be cultured in a cell-free medium

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mycoplasma pneumonia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Responds well to amoxiclav

 

Beta-lactam groups of drugs act by inhibiting the transpeptidation process of cell wall synthesis. Mycoplasma does not possess a cell wall and hence is not affected by beta-lactams.
