Azithromycin (DOC), Doxycycline, Fluoroquinolone (FQ) are effective in management of mycoplasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interstitial inflammation characterized by bilateral reticular infiltrates are seen on CXR.

 

Option C. IgM, IgG can be used in the diagnosis of Mycoplasma.

 

Option D. They show fried-egg appearance on cell free medium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma pneumonia does not respond to beta-lactam antibiotics due to its lack of a cell wall.

 

The preferred antibiotics for treating Mycoplasma pneumonia include macrolides (e.g., azithromycin), tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline), and fluoroquinolones for adults.

 

Reference - Resp Med/pneumonia, Harrison chap 188/5430

questions.text:
Which of the following is True regarding drugs used for viral infections?

 

  1. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir
  2. Ombitasvir is inhibitor of proteins synthesis
  3. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata
  4. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C
  5. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu
questions.solution:
Ans. A. C, D and E

 

C. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata: This statement is true. Imiquimod is an immunomodulator used for the treatment of various viral warts, including condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

 

D. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C: This statement is true. Simprevir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HCV, which works by inhibiting the NS3/4A protease enzyme necessary for viral replication.

 

E. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu: This statement is true. Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication effective against influenza A (including H5N1 and H1N1, commonly known as swine flu) and influenza B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir: This statement is false. Ribavirin, when used for the treatment of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV), must be combined with injectable interferons, which have significant adverse effects. Sofosbuvir, a newer oral drug that inhibits the NS5B RNA polymerase, is preferred over ribavirin due to its better efficacy and fewer side effects.

 

Option B. Ombitasvir is an inhibitor of protein synthesis: This statement is false. Ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, meaning it acts by inhibiting viral RNA replication and assembly of the hepatitis C virus (HCV), not protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sofosbuvir is preferred over ribavirin for HCV treatment due to better efficacy, ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, imiquimod is used for condyloma acuminata, simprevir inhibits HCV protease, and oseltamivir is used for swine flu.

 

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 853,856,858

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented to OPD of a PHC Watery diarrhea having severe dehydration. Most likely causative agent underlying would be: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Rota virus

 

  • Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea among young children, especially those under 5 years of age. 
  • Rotavirus primarily affects the small intestine, causing malabsorption and secretory diarrhea, which can lead to rapid dehydration. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shigella: Incorrect. Shigella invades the colonic mucosa, causing inflammation and ulceration, which results in the characteristic bloody stools with mucus. It is not the most common cause of watery diarrhea with severe dehydration in young children.

 

Option B. E.Coli O157:H7: Incorrect. E. coli O157:H7 is an enterohemorrhagic strain that primarily causes bloody diarrhea, not watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Incorrect. Salmonella typically causes gastroenteritis with diarrhea, fever, vomiting and is usually accompanied by abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the most common cause of watery diarrhea with severe dehydration in young children under 5 years of age.

choices.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle
Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle
Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles
It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormones are true, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is best tested in the fasting state on day 2 of menstrual cycle

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the Sertoli cells in males and the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in females. It serves as a marker of ovarian reserve and is crucial in assessing fertility potential. Here are the reasons why option A is incorrect:

 

  • AMH Testing: Unlike some other hormones, AMH does not require fasting and can be tested at any time during the menstrual cycle. The timing of testing AMH is not restricted to day 2 of the menstrual cycle as with some other reproductive hormone assessments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein from granulosa cell of early antral follicle: This is a true statement. AMH is indeed a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of early antral follicles in the ovaries.

 

Option C. Correlates with pregnancy rate of IVF cycles: This is also true. AMH levels correlate with ovarian reserve and can give an indication of the likelihood of a successful IVF cycle. Higher levels generally suggest a better response to ovarian stimulation and thus potentially higher pregnancy rates.

 

Option D. It decreases sensitivity of the pre-antral follicles to FSH: This statement is correct. AMH reduces the sensitivity of pre-antral and small antral follicles to Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which is a mechanism to regulate follicle recruitment and maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) does not need to be tested in the fasting state or specifically on day 2 of the menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 76, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA)
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)
Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, and tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)

 

The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a condition commonly seen in diabetes patients with high blood sugar levels (RBS: 450 mg/dL). The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are characteristic of DKA.

 

The laboratory values indicate a metabolic acidosis:

 

  • pH of 7.34: Slightly acidic, indicating acidosis.
  • Bicarbonate of 12 mmol/L: Low, consistent with metabolic acidosis.
  • Chloride of 92 mmol/L: Lower than normal.

 

To determine the type of metabolic acidosis, we calculate the anion gap:

 

 

An anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L indicates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). In this case, the anion gap is 31, confirming HAGMA. 

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is typically associated with conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, renal failure, and ingestion of toxins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA): This occurs when the anion gap is normal (less than 12 mmol/L). Conditions that cause NAGMA include diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis. This does not match the patient's high anion gap.

 

Option C. Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis: This condition involves an elevated pH with high bicarbonate levels. The patient’s pH is acidic, not alkalotic, and bicarbonate is low.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Characterized by a primary increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels leading to a low pH. The patient’s primary disturbance is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by an anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L, indicating an accumulation of unmeasured anions. This condition is often seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, which presents with elevated blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of passive immunity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoid

 

Passive immunity occurs when antibodies are transferred to an individual without stimulating their immune system. The key characteristic of passive immunity is that it provides immediate but temporary protection, as it doesn't involve the host's immune system actively producing antibodies. Passive immunity can be acquired naturally (through maternal transfer) or artificially (through immunoglobulin administration).

 

A toxoid, being a modified form of bacterial toxin, actually stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies, making it a form of active immunity rather than passive immunity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Antitoxin: Incorrect because antitoxins are preformed antibodies against specific toxins. When administered, they provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, making them a true example of passive immunity.

 

Option C. IgA: Incorrect because maternal IgA transferred through breast milk is a classic example of naturally acquired passive immunity, providing immediate protection to infants.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibodies: Incorrect because these are laboratory-produced antibodies that provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, representing artificial passive immunity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Passive immunity involves direct antibody transfer without immune system stimulation, while active immunity (like toxoids) involves stimulating the immune system to produce its own antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for uncomplicated malaria? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Artemether

 

According to the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Program guidelines, artemisinin derivatives like artemether should never be given alone as it promotes resistance. For uncomplicated malaria treatment in India, the protocol depends on the Plasmodium species. 

 

  • For P. vivax and P. ovale, chloroquine is used along with primaquine. 
  • For P. falciparum or P. malariae, artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is used along with primaquine.

 

In other parts of India artesunate is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine and primaquine, while in northeast India, artemether is combined with lumefantrine and primaquine. Using artemether alone is explicitly prohibited by the program as it can lead to drug resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin derivatives like artemether should never be given alone for malaria treatment as they promote resistance. They must always be used in combination therapy (ACT).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) was described by the WHO in 2007 and involves mainly three basic steps:

 

  1. Administering a uterotonic: Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV).
  2. Controlled cord traction: This is done only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
  3. Uterine massage: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who have received uterotonics; instead, postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.

 

Key Points:

 

  • AMTSL prevents atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care. This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed.

 

WHO Guidelines:

 

  • In 2012:
    • Emphasized the main three steps.
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice.
    • Controlled cord traction only with a skilled birth attendant.
    • Delayed cord clamping recommended.
  • In 2018:
    • Additional uterotonics that can be used include:
      • Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV)
      • Misoprostol (400 or 600 mcg PO – to be used where a skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
      • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV except in hypertensive women)
      • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
    • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonics after delivery of placenta: This is a key component of AMTSL to prevent atonic PPH.

 

Option B. Controlled cord traction: This is part of the AMTSL process to help deliver the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine massage: This is included in AMTSL, specifically for assessing uterine tone post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ligature mark

 

A ligature mark is a well-known pressure mark on the neck underneath a ligature. It is a common injury in cases of hanging and strangulation.

 

Ligature Mark:

 

  • Appearance: Typically presents as a horizontal or slightly diagonal mark around the neck.
  • Cause: Caused by the application of a ligature (e.g., rope, cord, or similar object) under tension.
  • Context: Commonly associated with homicidal, suicidal, or accidental hanging and strangulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graze abrasion: Caused by scraping or sliding friction against a rough surface, resulting in superficial loss of skin.

 

Option C. Brush burns: Result from friction burns, often appearing as red, inflamed, and abraded areas of skin.

 

Option D. Imprint abrasion: Caused by the impact of a patterned object, leaving an imprint on the skin.

 

Educational objective

 

Types of abrasions:

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sublingual gland

 

In a radical neck dissection, the aim is to remove extensive lymphatic tissue potentially involved with malignancies, but the procedure generally spares certain non-lymphatic structures unless directly involved by the tumor. The sublingual gland, which is located under the floor of the mouth, is not typically removed during a radical neck dissection because it is not within the field of the lymph node groups that are typically excised. This gland remains intact unless the specific tumor pathology dictates otherwise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid may be removed if it is involved with the tumor or if the dissection needs to be extended to ensure comprehensive removal of cancerous tissues.

 

Option C. Submandibular gland: This gland is typically removed during radical neck dissections because it lies within the Level I lymph nodes, which are included in the dissection.

 

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: These are generally removed in a radical neck dissection, which traditionally includes the removal of lymph nodes from Levels I to V.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition Page No. 442; Stell and Maran 5th edition Page No. 710

choices.text: Matzke scale
Salazar scale
Rummack-mathew scale

questions.text: Vancomycin nomogram is known as (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Matzke scale

 

The Vancomycin nomogram is also known as the Matzke nomogram or the Matzke scale. It is a tool used to help predict the appropriate dose of vancomycin, an antibiotic, based on the patient's creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration. The nomogram is a graphical representation that allows healthcare providers to quickly and easily determine the optimal dose of vancomycin for a given patient, taking into account factors such as kidney function and the patient's weight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salazar scale: This nomogram is not related to vancomycin dosing. It is used to predict overall survival of patients with cancer.

 

Option C. Rummack-Matthew scale: This is used to assess potential hepatotoxicity after acetaminophen intake based on serum acetaminophen concentration.

 

Option D. Krutzko scale: There is no widely recognized medical scale or nomogram known as the Krutzko scale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vancomycin nomogram, also known as the Matzke scale, is a crucial tool for determining the appropriate dosing of vancomycin based on creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration, ensuring both efficacy and safety in patient treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given HE image? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatic valvular disease

 

The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease. During acute Rheumatic Fever (RF), focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues. Distinctive lesions occur in the heart, called Aschoff bodies, which consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to ovoid nuclei in which the chromatin is disposed in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”) and may become multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Infective endocarditis is characterized by large, friable vegetations composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms, which would not exhibit the Aschoff bodies seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Myxoma: Myxomas are benign tumors of the heart that typically present as a gelatinous mass, and they do not feature Aschoff bodies or the inflammatory response seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can affect the heart but does not produce the Aschoff bodies characteristic of rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Aschoff bodies, characterized by foci of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and Anitschkow cells, is pathognomonic for rheumatic valvular disease and indicates a history of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no – 1044

questions.text: As a young pediatrician practicing in India, you attend various workshops and training sessions to keep yourself updated with the latest guidelines in child health. During one such session focused on India's National Immunization Program, you discuss with your colleagues about the range of vaccines included in the program. Which of the following vaccines is NOT currently part of India's National Immunization Program? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Influenza

 

  • The Influenza vaccine (commonly known as the Flu shot) has not yet been included in India's National Immunization Programme.
  • It's important to note that the Bacterial Hemophilus influenzae type-b (Hib) vaccine is distinct from the viral Influenza (Flu) vaccine.
  • The HiB vaccine is included as part of the pentavalent vaccine (DPT + HiB + HepB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

choices.text: 10-year-old child with multi organ dysfunction syndrome
49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence
74-year-old woman with end stage renal disease

questions.text: In the case of a 37-year-old woman who has been declared brain dead and whose family has agreed to donate her organs, who would be the most suitable or optimal candidate to receive the organs? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31-year-old women with renal failure

 

This candidate is closer in age to the donor, and if her medical condition and compatibility allow for a successful kidney transplant, she may be the most suitable recipient for the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 10-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome: This candidate is likely in urgent need of multiple organ transplantation, and a younger recipient may generally have better long-term outcomes. However, etiology of multi-organ dysfunction is not provided, thereby the long term prognosis of the patient is uncertain.

 

Option B. A 49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence: While this candidate may benefit from a liver transplant, alcoholism can pose challenges to transplantation success. The one-month abstinence period is relatively short, and further evaluation of his liver condition and suitability for transplantation would be necessary.

 

Option C. A 74-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease: Given the age of the recipient and the fact that she has end-stage renal disease, a kidney transplant from the 37-year-old donor may not provide the best long-term outcomes. Older recipients may have a lower life expectancy, and the benefit of a kidney transplant may be less significant compared to younger recipients.

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

questions.text: A patient who was on a ventilator for one week suddenly gets agitated and self-extubates himself. What is the next step of management? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

 

  • This is the most logical and safest immediate action. By observing the patient's spontaneous breathing, clinicians can gauge whether the patient is in distress or if they're maintaining their airway and oxygenating adequately. Self-extubation doesn't automatically necessitate re-intubation. If the patient is breathing well and does not desaturate, self-extubated patients may not require re-intubation. This can be confirmed by doing an arterial blood gas of the patient and checking his PaO2/FiO2 ratio and also watching for spontaneous breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Re-intubate: Simply re-intubating without assessment can be a precipitous action. It might be unnecessary if the patient can maintain their airway and oxygenation without assistance. Additionally, re-intubation has its own set of risks, including injury to the airway, so it's not a decision to be taken lightly.

 

Option B. Oxygenate and re-intubate: While it's always important to ensure a patient is well-oxygenated, especially if there's potential for re-intubation, the decision to re-intubate should be based on the patient's clinical status and not solely on the fact that they've self-extubated.

 

Option C. Start CPR: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is initiated in situations of cardiac arrest. There's no indication in the scenario that the patient's heart has stopped. Starting CPR without evidence of cardiac arrest can cause harm, including broken ribs and internal injury.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Self-extubation requires careful assessment to determine if re-intubation is necessary. Observing the patient's spontaneous breathing and oxygenation status is crucial before making the decision to re-intubate.

questions.text: All of the following are true about grey rami communicants is all except: (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Preganglionic

 

Explanation:

 

  • The grey rami communicantes are not preganglionic fibers. They are postganglionic fibers.
  • In contrast, the white rami communicantes carry preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the spinal nerve to the sympathetic chain ganglia. Once in the ganglia, these fibers either synapse with postganglionic neurons, which return via the grey rami to spinal nerves, or ascend or descend to synapse at other levels.
  • The sympathetic trunks on either side of the vertebral columns consist of a series of ganglia. They are connected to the spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicantes. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic neurons are located in the lateral horn in the spinal grey matter. They leave the cord in the ventral nerve roots to form spinal nerves. These fibers enter the sympathetic trunk in white rami communicantes.
  • They synapse with the postganglionic sympathetic neurons in the sympathetic ganglia. The axons of the postganglionic neurons return to the spinal nerve through the grey rami communicantes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unmyelinated: True. Grey rami communicantes primarily contain unmyelinated postganglionic sympathetic fibers. These fibers are responsible for conveying the postganglionic sympathetic impulses to the spinal nerves, which then distribute these impulses to their target tissues.

 

Option B. Connected to spinal nerve: True. Grey rami communicantes connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to the adjacent spinal nerves. They are responsible for transmitting postganglionic sympathetic fibers to all spinal nerves (regardless of whether or not the spinal nerve level has a white ramus communicans).

 

Option D. Present medial to white rami communicantes: True. Anatomically, when observing the sympathetic chain and its connections to the spinal nerves, the grey rami communicantes are located medially (or more centrally) relative to the white rami communicantes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grey rami communicantes contain postganglionic, unmyelinated fibers that connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to spinal nerves, facilitating the distribution of sympathetic impulses to the body, contrasting with the preganglionic fibers found in white rami communicantes.

questions.text: Choose the egg belonging to the following parasite from the column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

The above worm is Enterobius vermicularis

 

Adults are short, white, fusiform worms with pointed ends, looking like bits of white thread. The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like curricular expansions (cervical alae), which are transversely striated. as seen in the image provided in the question. The esophagus has a double bulb structure, a feature unique to this worm.

 

 

The egg is colorless and not bile-stained. It floats in saturated salt solution. It has a characteristic shape, being elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other (planoconvex), measuring 50-60 μm by 20-30 μm. The eggshell is double-layered and relatively thick, though transparent. The outer albuminous layer makes the eggs stick to each other and to clothing and other objects. The egg contains a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo, which is fully formed, but becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited on the skin. Under cool moist conditions, the egg remains viable for about 2 weeks.

 

 

The correctly matched egg for the given parasite - Enterobius vermicularis is 3

 

Other choices:
 

Option A: Egg of Hymenolepsis nana
 

Option B: Egg of Tenia species 
 

Option D: Fertilized egg of ascaris
 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis eggs are elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other, with a double-layered, thick, transparent shell and contain a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo.

choices.text: Increased Amino acids
Raised glucose

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus comes with dizziness. Which of the following would be seen in a patient with hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased fatty acid synthesis

 

Explanation:  

 

Hyperinsulinemia refers to an elevated level of insulin in the blood.

 

Insulin is a lipogenic hormone, meaning it promotes the synthesis of fatty acids and their storage as triglycerides in adipose tissue. This is due to insulin's ability to activate enzymes involved in lipogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper-ketonemia: Incorrect. Insulin suppresses ketone production, so hyperinsulinemia would prevent the formation of ketone bodies.

 

Option B. Increased Amino acids: Incorrect. Insulin promotes protein synthesis and reduces the level of amino acids in the blood by enhancing their uptake into cells and their incorporation into proteins.

 

Option C. Raised glucose: Incorrect. Hyperinsulinemia lowers blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and inhibiting gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperinsulinemia promotes increased fatty acid synthesis due to insulin's role as a lipogenic hormone, which enhances the storage of energy in the form of fat.

questions.text: A female patient was clinically diagnosed to have hypothyroidism. Measurements of the following parameters were obtained: TSH; combined protein levels; and total and free T3, T4, and rT3. Which one of the following options represents her condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

Laboratory investigations in a patient with hypothyroidism would show low levels of total and free T3, T4, and rT3 with high TSH levels, and normal combined protein levels.

 

Normally, the hypothalamus releases thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), which stimulates the pituitary gland to release thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). TSH then stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4. When thyroid hormone production is deficient (hypothyroidism), TSH levels rise in an attempt to stimulate the gland further.

 

  • Elevated TSH with low free T4 levels is indicative of primary hypothyroidism.
  • In contrast, secondary hypothyroidism (due to pituitary failure) would show low TSH and low T3/T4 levels.
  • Tertiary hypothyroidism (due to hypothalamic dysfunction) also results in low TSH and low T3/T4.

 

Patients with hypothyroidism typically present with fatigue, dry skin, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, bradycardia, and depression. Physical findings may include cool extremities, puffy face, and periorbital edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 (High T3, T4, and Low TSH): This combination suggests hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

 

Option B. 2 (Low T3, T4, Normal TSH): This could indicate euthyroid sick syndrome rather than primary hypothyroidism.

 

Option C. 3 (High T3, T4, Normal TSH): This may represent conditions with normal thyroid function or thyroid hormone resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In primary hypothyroidism, you typically see low free T3 and T4 levels with elevated TSH. Proper diagnosis and management are crucial, and hypothyroidism is often treated with levothyroxine to normalize hormone levels.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After few months of treatment, he develops palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation. What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emtricitabine


Emtricitabine is an NRTI (Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor) which can lead to hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles.

 

Other options:


Option A. Nelfinavir is a protease inhibitor. It can cause diarrhea or loose stools, dyslipidemia, lipodystrophy and hyperlipidemia.


Option C. Abacavir is an NRTI that can lead to Steven Johnson Syndrome.


Option D. Zidovudine is an NRTI that can cause nail hyperpigmentation, bone marrow suppression, myopathy, hepatotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine, an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV, is known to cause palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation as a side effect. This differentiates it from other antiretroviral medications such as nelfinavir, abacavir, and zidovudine, which have different side effect profiles.

questions.text: A woman with 31 weeks of gestation presents with lower abdominal pain. The clinician is concerned if the patient is in preterm labor. Which of the following is the most appropriate test in this scenario? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal fibronectin

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal fibronectin (fFN) is a glycoprotein produced by fetal amnion cells and found in high concentrations in amniotic fluid. It is also found in cervico-vaginal secretions in early pregnancy (less than 22 weeks) and late pregnancy (greater than 37 weeks). The presence of fFN in cervico-vaginal secretions between 22 and 37 weeks is used as a predictor of preterm labor.

 

A fFN level greater than 50 ng/mL is considered a significant predictor of preterm labor. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) does not recommend routine use of fFN testing but it can be helpful in specific clinical scenarios where preterm labor is suspected.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Alpha fetoprotein: Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is used in prenatal screening for neural tube defects and as a component of the quadruple marker test for Down syndrome. Elevated AFP levels are associated with neural tube defects, while decreased levels can indicate Down syndrome.

 

Option B. Beta HCG: Beta HCG is used in early pregnancy for confirming pregnancy and in first trimester screening for Down syndrome (where levels are elevated). It is not used for diagnosing preterm labor.

 

Option D. PAPP-A: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is used in first trimester screening for Down syndrome, where its levels are decreased. It is not used for diagnosing preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal fibronectin (fFN) testing is the most appropriate test for assessing the risk of preterm labor in a woman presenting with lower abdominal pain at 31 weeks of gestation. A positive fFN test (greater than 50 ng/mL) can help predict the likelihood of preterm labor.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 366

questions.text: What is the optimal urine output for a patient who has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour

 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is anticipated that the patient will have a normal urine output during the postoperative phase, which is 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour.

 

If converted into ml/day, approximately 1500 ml/day in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/minute, approximately 1 to 1.5 ml/minute in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/kg, approximately 12-36 ml/day in an avg. adult

choices.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution
Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries
To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.text: You are a researcher studying global mortality rates, and you notice substantial differences in the age structures of various countries. Recognizing that direct comparisons could be misleading due to these differences, you explore methods to equalize or adjust the mortality data to get a more accurate comparative view. In your research, you come across the term "standardized age mortality ratio." Which of the following best describes this concept? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution 

 

The standardized age mortality ratio serves as an indicator for the population's mortality rate adjusted to a standardized age distribution.

 

Standardization of Death Rates

 

  • While comparison of death rates of two populations, ‘crude death rate is not the right yardstick’, as age-compositions are different
  • Age-adjustment or age-standardization removes confounding effect of different age structures
  • Standardization may be direct or indirect
  • Standardization is carried out beginning by using a ‘Standard Population’

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution: Incorrect. Standardization typically adjusts for age, not sex.

 

Option C. Removal of bias due to different age group populations in different countries: Incorrect. This describes the purpose of age standardization, not the definition of standardized age mortality ratio.

 

Option D. To eliminate age structure of different countries: Incorrect. Age standardization accounts for, but does not eliminate, age structure differences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standardized age mortality ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, allowing for more accurate comparisons between populations with different age structures.

 

Additional Information

 

Types of Standardized Death Rates

 

Direct standardization:

 

  • Method:
    • Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied 
    • on a standard population
    • Total expected deaths calculated
    • Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • Feasibility:
    • Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR)
    • Availability of population in each age group

 

Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form

 

  • Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population
  • Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers
  • Examples of indirect Standardization:

  • Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100

  • Life Table Analysis

  • Survival Analysis

questions.text: In the case of a patient presenting with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face, which drug is considered the preferred choice for treatment?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotretinoin

 

This is a case of nodular acne. It comes under grade IV/severe acne.

 

Oral isotretinoin, an oral retinoid is indicated for the treatment of severe acne (nodular, acne conglobata & recalcitrant acne.

 

Recalcitrant acne is poorly responsive acne, with less than 50% improvement after 6 months of therapy with combined oral & topical antibiotics.

 

ACNE VULGARIS:

 

  • Most common form of acne.
  • Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.
  • Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.
  • Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris

 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or whitehead .

 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Stages of acne

 

 

According to Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment:

 

 

 

BPO= Benzoyl peroxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids particularly corticosteroids, can reduce inflammation and are sometimes used to treat severe inflammatory conditions. However, systemic corticosteroids are generally not a first-line treatment for nodulocystic acne because of their potential side effects, including exacerbating acne upon withdrawal. Intralesional corticosteroids can be used for large, painful nodules but are not the primary treatment for widespread nodulocystic acne.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: It is an antibiotic that can be used to treat acne due to its antibacterial effects against Cutibacterium acnes (formerly Propionibacterium acnes), the bacteria partly responsible for acne. However, it is not as effective as isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and is generally used for less severe forms or when other treatments are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: It is another class of antibiotics used in the treatment of acne. While tetracyclines can be effective for inflammatory acne, they are typically less effective than isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and are not the preferred treatment in such cases.

 

Educational Objective::

 

Isotretinoin is the preferred treatment for severe nodulocystic acne due to its comprehensive action on reducing sebum production, decreasing inflammation, and normalizing keratinization.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.7 & 90.37

questions.text: A 36-year-old male came with complaints of ascending weakness in both lower limb and upper body. There was no history of trauma. Which of the following is the next investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum Potassium

 

Disturbance in serum potassium levels (hypokalemia or hyperkalemia) present with ascending muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Magnesium: Incorrect for this scenario as disturbances in magnesium typically cause tetany (muscle spasms) when low and generalized weakness when high, but are less directly linked to the type of ascending muscle weakness described.

 

Option C. Serum Sodium: Incorrect because changes in serum sodium levels generally affect neurological function but do not typically cause muscular weakness.

 

Option D. Serum Calcium: Incorrect as calcium imbalances would more likely cause tetany (from hypocalcemia) or symptoms like fatigue, depression, and cardiac arrhythmias (from hypercalcemia), rather than ascending muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The disturbances in serum potassium levels can manifest as muscle weakness, making it a vital test in cases of unexplained, ascending muscle weakness without trauma.

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inhaled lead dust

 

  • In industrial environments such as battery manufacturing factories, the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption is through inhalation of lead dust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic

 

  • Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol/vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical picture of lead poisoning:

 

  • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • Lead encephalopathy
  • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).

 

Treatment: EDTA

choices.text: In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors
Upper third molar is most commonly absent in Mongolians
Prominent lingual ridge and labial ridge in mongols

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding teeth and ethnicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors

 

The cusps of molars are wide and deep and cusps of incisors are shovel-shaped is typically seen in Mongoloid races not in Africanoids hence the statement is incorrect. In Africanoids there is presence of large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

 

Option B), Option C), Option D): these statements are correct as explained in the core concept above. The question is asking for the wrong statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key differences between race

questions.text: The loading dose of a drug is governed primarily by? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Volume of distribution

 

Loading dose = Volume of Distribution * Target plasma concentration.

 

Loading dose is the high initial dose of the drug that is initially given to cover the distribution so that the desired action can take place. In other words, when the time to reach a steady-state is long, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the target concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance: Clearance is a measure of the body's efficiency in eliminating the drug but does not determine the loading dose. It is more relevant to the maintenance dose.

 

Option C. Plasma half-life: The half-life of a drug determines how long it stays in the body but is not directly used to calculate the loading dose.

 

Option D. Bioavailability: Bioavailability refers to the fraction of the administered dose that reaches the systemic circulation. While important for understanding the effective dose, it does not govern the calculation of the loading dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loading dose of a drug is primarily governed by its volume of distribution, which helps achieve the desired plasma concentration quickly, especially when the drug has a long half-life.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is released from SA node in response to increase in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetylcholine

 

Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter released by the parasympathetic nervous system. When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch detect this change and stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system. This leads to the release of acetylcholine from the vagus nerve at the SA node, resulting in a decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) and a reduction in cardiac output, which helps to lower blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter involved in several central nervous system functions, including movement and reward. It is not directly involved in the regulation of heart rate or blood pressure in the context of the SA node.

 

Option C. Epinephrine: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is released by the adrenal medulla and acts on both alpha and beta adrenergic receptors. It generally increases heart rate and blood pressure. It is not released from the SA node in response to increased blood pressure.

 

Option D. Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is a neurotransmitter released by the sympathetic nervous system. It acts on alpha and beta adrenergic receptors to increase heart rate and blood pressure. However, in response to increased blood pressure, the sympathetic activity is typically reduced, and norepinephrine release is decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the correct neurotransmitter released from the SA node in response to an increase in blood pressure is acetylcholine, as it is part of the parasympathetic response to decrease heart rate and lower blood pressure.
